Headline.Para: Changi's T2 to undergo major facelift

LeadPara.Para: Works to start in 2019; planned upgrades include new check-in areas and counters
Changi Airport Terminal 2 will undergo a major facelift, with works expected to start next year and end by 2024, The Straits Times has learnt.

TailParas.Para: The works at T2 will include several upgrades, including new check-in areas and counters so that more self-service options for passengers can be rolled out.
The baggage-handling system will allow for more automation - and be operated by fewer people - to sort early check-in bags, for example.
The latest baggage systems are already in place at the other three terminals.

The works are expected to increase capacity at the terminal, which can now handle about 22 million passengers a year, by another three million to five million, ST understands. The boost will be much needed as Changi Airport, which handled a record 62.2 million passengers last year, expects to continue to grow as it taps a growing demand for air travel in the region.
The current upgrading works at T1 and the construction of Jewel Changi Airport are almost complete as Changi continually spruces up to stay ahead of rival airports.
Upgrades at Changi Airport
$240 million upgrade of T2 is completed. Enhancements include new commercial areas for shopping and dining, and the construction of a 250m-long leaf-shaped glass canopy at the departure kerbside.
Opening of T3, which costs $1.75 billion.
$500 million upgrade of T1 is completed to add extra space, among other improvements.
A highlight in the departure hall is the world's largest kinetic art sculpture, Kinetic Rain. The sculpture is made up of a total of 1,216 bronze droplets.
Opening of T4, which costs about $985 million.

Jewel Changi Airport, with five storeys above ground and five basement levels, will open. T1's arrival hall will be integrated with the complex, while T2's and T3's public areas will be connected via link bridges.
2019 Major upgrading works to start at T2.
2020s Three runways will be up and running.
2030s T5 expected to open. It can initially handle 50 million passengers a year.
T2 last went under the knife in 2003, with a $240 million upgrading project. Since then, the other terminals have caught up.

Regular traveller Annie Lim, 38, a marketing executive, said: "T2 is nice and good, compared with many other airport terminals around the region. But when you compare it with the other terminals at Changi, it does look a bit dated, and the lighting is not very good either, so it looks a bit dark in places."

Singapore Airlines (SIA) spokesman Nicholas Ionides said the planned upgrades will improve the efficiency of the airline's operations and "create a better travel experience" for its customers at Changi.

German carrier Lufthansa, which also operates at T2, is confident the planned enhancements will offer the latest technologies that will bring increased efficiencies and convenience for the airline and its passengers, a spokesman said.
Even as the upgrades are welcomed, travellers can expect some inconvenience when the hoardings go up and work starts.

The Lufthansa spokesman said: "Like for all major renovation projects, we might need to deal with some temporary infrastructural limitations, but we always work closely with the airport to minimise disruptions in order to maintain our daily operations smoothly."

Mr Ionides said SIA does not expect major disruptions on operations during the works but will work closely with the airport authorities, as well as ground handling agents and partners, to ensure minimal inconvenience to customers.
